descriptions: Demonstrates no understanding of the health risks associated with tobacco smoke.
Demonstrates a minimal understanding of the health risks; may confuse them or state them inaccurately.
Demonstrates a basic understanding of some health risks, such as lung cancer, but lacks depth or detail.
Demonstrates a solid understanding of several health risks, including respiratory issues and cardiovascular problems.
Demonstrates a comprehensive understanding of a wide range of health risks, including short-term and long-term effects.
Demonstrates an exceptional understanding of the health risks and can explain the biological mechanisms through which tobacco smoke harms the body.
Unable to identify any harmful components of tobacco smoke.
Identifies one or two harmful components but struggles to explain their effects.
Identifies several harmful components, such as nicotine and tar, but lacks detail in their explanations.
Identifies most of the major harmful components, including carcinogens and particulate matter, and briefly explains their effects.
Identifies a wide range of harmful components and provides detailed explanations of how they damage the body.
Identifies obscure and emerging harmful components, discussing their specific mechanisms of toxicity with precision.
Shows no awareness of the dangers of secondhand smoke.
Shows minimal awareness, possibly believing secondhand smoke is not very harmful.
Recognizes that secondhand smoke is harmful but lacks specific details.
Understands that secondhand smoke poses a risk to others, especially children and those with respiratory issues.
Explains the specific health risks associated with secondhand smoke, citing relevant statistics and research.
Expertly articulates the disproportionate impact of secondhand smoke on vulnerable populations, advocating for stricter public health policies with detailed understanding.
